div.p: London, on the first of August.
The Queen is in excellent spirits, and the people everywhere are thirsty for religion. The bishops prefer to vacate their positions rather than renounce the Pope.
In Scotland, everything is in turmoil.

Mr. Knox, surrounded by a thousand followers, holds assemblies throughout the entire kingdom; the old queen has been forced to confine herself for protection. The nobility, with united minds and forces, is restoring religion everywhere against all opposition; monasteries everywhere are being leveled to the ground, theatrical garments, sacrilegious chalices, idols, and altars are being burned; not even traces of the old superstition and idolatry are left.

The King of France, who is now reigning, writes that he is the King of Scotland and heir to England. Our people are very troubled by this; I do not know where things will erupt; perhaps, as it often happens, a common enemy will reconcile us with our Scottish neighbor. I have been designated as the Bishop of Salisbury.
"Copy of the letter from Mr. Jewel of England, Bishop of Salisbury."
